warning.warningDescription: tainted data might flow into a file path creation method
warning.warningMessage: Possible path-traversal injection into actual parameter "arg 0" of method "<init>"

warning.warningDescription: tainted data might flow into a file path creation method
warning.warningMessage: Possible path-traversal injection into actual parameter "arg 0" of method "<init>"

warning.warningDescription: tainted data might flow into a message sent by the device
warning.warningMessage: Sensitive data seems sent into actual parameter "arg 2" of method "getConnection"

warning.warningDescription: tainted data might flow into a reflection method
warning.warningMessage: Possible reflection-injection into actual parameter "arg 0" of method "forName"

warning.warningDescription: tainted data might flow into an sql query, unsanitized
warning.warningMessage: Possible SQL-injection into actual parameter "arg 0" of method "prepareStatement"

warning.warningDescription: tainted data might flow into an sql query, unsanitized
warning.warningMessage: Possible SQL-injection into actual parameter "arg 0" of method "prepareStatement"

warning.warningDescription: tainted data might flow into an sql query, unsanitized
warning.warningMessage: Possible SQL-injection into actual parameter "arg 0" of method "prepareStatement"

warning.warningDescription: tainted data might flow into an sql query, unsanitized
warning.warningMessage: Possible SQL-injection into actual parameter "arg 0" of method "prepareStatement"

booleanOption.label: Allow framework detection
booleanOption.name: allowFrameworkDetection
booleanOption.description: Enables automatic framework detection
booleanOption.documentation: Enables automatic framework detection, allowing Julia to identify frameworks and optimize the analysis accordingly. A description of the frameworks automatically recognized by Julia is available in the documentation

stringOption.label: Type of splitter
stringOption.name: applicationSplitter

alternative.name: ByPackage
alternative.synopsis: split the application jars on the basis of their packages structure

alternative.name: KargerSteinCut
alternative.synopsis: apply the Karger-Stein algorithm to partition the application jars

alternative.name: RandomDeterministic
alternative.synopsis: randomly split the application jars

alternative.name: StoerWagnerMinimumCut
alternative.synopsis: apply the Stoer-Wagner algorithm to partition the application jars

stringOption.documentation: Specifies the application splitter that must be used to split the application jars. By deafult, the random splitter is selected.

booleanOption.label: classifyForCS
booleanOption.name: classifyForCS
booleanOption.description: Add external classification for GrammaTech CodeSonar
booleanOption.documentation: If true, add the external classification CS-INT-CLASSIFICATION that is used by CodeSonarto categorize Security warnings

booleanOption.label: Dump call graph
booleanOption.name: dumpCallGraph
booleanOption.description: Dump the call graph generated by the analysis
booleanOption.documentation: Specifies whether or not the call graph computed by the analysis should be dumped to a dot file

booleanOption.label: Dump generated annotations
booleanOption.name: dumpFrameworkAnnotations
booleanOption.description: Dump annotations generated by framework specification
booleanOption.documentation: Specifies whether or not the annotations automatically generated by the application of a framework specification should be dumped or not

booleanOption.label: dumpOutputToLog
booleanOption.name: dumpOutputToLog
booleanOption.description: Dump warnings and remarks to standard output
booleanOption.documentation: If true, the complete list of warnings and remarks will be dumped to the standard output

booleanOption.label: Enable assertions
booleanOption.name: ea
booleanOption.description: Assume that assertions are turned on
booleanOption.documentation: Assume that assertion statements are executed, hence warnings should be reported about those statements and their effects on subsequent instructions must be taken into account

enumOption.label: Entry points
enumOption.name: entryPoint

alternative.name: ALL_ENTRIES
alternative.synopsis: Assume that all public and protected methods and constructors are entry points

alternative.name: ALL_METHODS
alternative.synopsis: Assume that all public, protected and private methods and constructors are entry points

alternative.name: LIBRARY
alternative.synopsis: Run in library mode

alternative.name: ONLY_EXPLICIT_ENTRIES
alternative.synopsis: Only consider entry points marked as @EntryPoint

alternative.name: ONLY_STANDARD_ENTRIES
alternative.synopsis: Only consider default entry points like main methods, event handlers of Swing and Android

enumOption.description: The entry points of the application
enumOption.documentation: Specify the entry point of the application the analysis starts from.

stringOption.label: Framework
stringOption.name: framework

alternative.name: androidAPI1
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 1

alternative.name: androidAPI10
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 10

alternative.name: androidAPI11
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 11

alternative.name: androidAPI12
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 12

alternative.name: androidAPI13
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 13

alternative.name: androidAPI14
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 14

alternative.name: androidAPI15
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 15

alternative.name: androidAPI16
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 16

alternative.name: androidAPI17
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 17

alternative.name: androidAPI18
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 18

alternative.name: androidAPI19
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 19

alternative.name: androidAPI2
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 2

alternative.name: androidAPI20
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 20

alternative.name: androidAPI21
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 21

alternative.name: androidAPI22
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 22

alternative.name: androidAPI23
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 23

alternative.name: androidAPI24
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 24

alternative.name: androidAPI25
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 25

alternative.name: androidAPI3
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 3

alternative.name: androidAPI4
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 4

alternative.name: androidAPI5
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 5

alternative.name: androidAPI6
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 6

alternative.name: androidAPI7
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 7

alternative.name: androidAPI8
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 8

alternative.name: androidAPI9
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Android API 9

alternative.name: dotnet
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for .NET

alternative.name: java1
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Java 1.1

alternative.name: java2
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Java 1.2

alternative.name: java3
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Java 1.3

alternative.name: java4
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Java 1.4

alternative.name: java5
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Java 1.5

alternative.name: java6
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Java 1.6

alternative.name: java7
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Java 1.7

alternative.name: java8
alternative.synopsis: use the framework of analysis for Java 1.8

stringOption.documentation: A framework specifies rules specific to the given programming context used for the application under analysis, such as the entry points for the analysis. The "java7" framework will work in most cases, but more specific frameworks might yield more precise results of analysis. The specification of the framework might also change the behavior of the checkers, since some checks might be sensible for some frameworks only

booleanOption.label: help
booleanOption.name: help
booleanOption.description: Display the help of the analyzer

booleanOption.label: Ignore XML files
booleanOption.name: ignoreXMLFiles
booleanOption.description: Ignore XML files regardless of content/type and support
booleanOption.documentation: Frameworks often rely on XML files to specify configuration and application behaviour.By default, Julia tries to parse common xml configuration files and simulate the implied runtime effects, this option forces Julia to ignore all input xml files regardless of the analysis support and optimizations provided by the selected framework.

enumOption.label: Mode of library processing
enumOption.name: libraryProcessingMode

alternative.name: TYPES
alternative.synopsis: ignore the code of the non-runtime libraries

alternative.name: TYPES_AND_CODE
alternative.synopsis: include the code of all classes during analysis

enumOption.documentation: Allow the analyzer to discard the implementation of library methods and only uses the hierarchy of the library classes during the analysis. This decreases the precision of the analysis and might occasionally make it unsound, but reduces the time of analysis.

booleanOption.label: maniac
booleanOption.name: maniac
booleanOption.description: Run in maniac mode
booleanOption.documentation: Applies very strict hypotheses about unknown code, such as reflective calls and calls with missing targets

intOption.label: maxMethods
intOption.name: maxMethods
intOption.description: Set the maximum number of extracted methods to N (0 means no limit)
intOption.documentation: After this threshold, the analysis aborts

booleanOption.label: mergeArrays
booleanOption.name: mergeArrays
booleanOption.description: Merge, during the extraction of the application, the arrays of the same type
booleanOption.documentation: This allows you to analyze applications that create a large number of arrays at many program points. This option might sometimes slightly reduce the precision of the analysis, by considering a larger number of methods and fields as reachable. However, it might be important for the analysis of some application, since it improves the scalability of the analyzer

booleanOption.label: mergeArraysInsideMethod
booleanOption.name: mergeArraysInsideMethod
booleanOption.description: Merge, during the extraction of the application, the arrays of the same type created inside the same method or constructor
booleanOption.documentation: This allows the user to analyze applications that create a large number of arrays at many program points. This option might sometimes slightly reduce the precision of the analysis, by considering a larger number of methods and fields as reachable. However, it might be important for the analysis of some application, since it improves the scalability of the analyzer. This option is less radical than the -mergeArrays option, that is, it introduces less imprecison but also induces less scalability

stringOption.label: outputPath
stringOption.name: outputPath
stringOption.description: Set the directory where the output of the analyzer must be dumped
stringOption.documentation: If that directory does not exist, it is automatically created by the analyzer

booleanOption.label: Robust
booleanOption.name: robust
booleanOption.description: Do not crash if a checker crashes
booleanOption.documentation: If a checker crashes (for any reason), the overall analysis goes ahead and terminates.A warning stating that <checker> crashed is produced in the console.

booleanOption.label: rta
booleanOption.name: rta
booleanOption.description: Use rapid type analysis to extract the application
booleanOption.documentation: This is rarely used and currently not optimized for large applications. The precision of rapid type analysis is worse than that of the standard extraction algorithm used by Julia but, in principle, should scale better. Please consider using the -mergeArrays and -mergeArraysInsideMethod options instead

stringOption.label: runtime
stringOption.name: runtime
stringOption.description: Specify the classpath used for loading the runtime classes
stringOption.documentation: Runtime classes are normally loaded by using the default class loader. This option allows one to change this behavior, by specifying a specific class path to use for class loading of runtime classes

booleanOption.label: sequential
booleanOption.name: sequential
booleanOption.description: Run checkers one after another
booleanOption.documentation: Instruct Julia to wait for the completion of a checker before starting running another checker

booleanOption.label: silent
booleanOption.name: silent
booleanOption.description: Run in silent mode
booleanOption.documentation: No textual output is produced with this option, but the analyses are run and output files are generated

intOption.label: Number of splits
intOption.name: splitApplicationJar
intOption.description: Split statistically closed jars, containing the application to analyse, into the given number of partitions
intOption.documentation: Splits the jars containing the application to analyse. This decreases the precision of the analysis and might occasionally make it unsound, but reduces the time of analysis

booleanOption.label: verbose
booleanOption.name: verbose
booleanOption.description: Run in verbose mode
booleanOption.documentation: This produces a longer and more detailed textual output. Mostly useful for debugging the analyzer

enumOption.label: bddType
enumOption.name: bddType

alternative.name: javaBDDs
alternative.synopsis: use the JavaBDD binary decision diagram library. See http://javabdd.sourceforge.net/

alternative.name: juliaBDDs
alternative.synopsis: use Julia's multithreaded binary decision diagram library

alternative.name: nativeBDDs
alternative.synopsis: use the native C-based binary decision diagram library

enumOption.description: specify the binary decision diagram library that must be used
enumOption.documentation: The native binary decision diagrams (BDD) library is in general faster (10% time reduction) than the Java versions but requires that that library be compiled, into native code, on the machine where the analysis is performed. Note, moreover, that the native library cannot be used for concurrent executions (for instance, inside a servlet container). The Julia library is multithreaded and can consequently be shared by many concurrent analyses, which reduces the memory footprint

booleanOption.label: dumpAnalysis
booleanOption.name: dumpAnalysis
booleanOption.description: dump extensive (very large!) log information about the analysis
booleanOption.documentation: Only useful for debugging the analyzer

booleanOption.label: dumpCompleteGraphs
booleanOption.name: dumpCompleteGraphs
booleanOption.description: dump the complete backward flow graph derivated from a sink
booleanOption.documentation: If set to true, it produces an archive with the complete backward flow graphs that are used for the extraction of source-sink subgraphs

booleanOption.label: dumpDotWithInvariants
booleanOption.name: dumpDotWithInvariants
booleanOption.description: dump the analysed code in dot format, with flow information
booleanOption.documentation: This option dumps a dot file for each method or constructor that is reachable from the entry points of the analysis. At the beginning of each code, a flow invariant is reported

booleanOption.label: flow
booleanOption.name: flow
booleanOption.description: where possible, reconstructs the instruction flows leading to injection issues
booleanOption.documentation: If true, it reconstructs the flow and provides detailed information on the warning if successful.

enumOption.label: flowComputingSpeed
enumOption.name: flowComputingSpeed

alternative.name: AVERAGE
alternative.synopsis: reconstruct graphs until max of 2000 nodes

alternative.name: FAST
alternative.synopsis: reconstruct graphs until max of 1000 nodes

alternative.name: FASTEST
alternative.synopsis: reconstruct graphs until max of 500 nodes

alternative.name: SLOW
alternative.synopsis: reconstruct graphs until max of 4000 nodes

alternative.name: SLOWEST
alternative.synopsis: reconstruct graphs until max of integer limit nodes

enumOption.documentation: This speciefies the efficiency of the flow reconstruct. Interesting only if option flow is set to true. (AVERAGE by default)

booleanOption.label: fullJaif
booleanOption.name: fullJaif
booleanOption.description: dump a jaif file with the information flow information of the program, containing both the selected properties of interest and their complement
booleanOption.documentation: The generated jaif file is a compact report of the program places that might contain a secret (tainted) value. Differently from the -jaif option, this generates explicit information for the places that contain a non-secret value as well and is hence a more verbose version of the same information

booleanOption.label: fullyQualifiedNames
booleanOption.name: fullyQualifiedNames
booleanOption.description: use fully qualified class names in the jaif files
booleanOption.documentation: The generated jaif file is a compact report of the program places that might contain a secret (tainted) value. This option forces the use of fully qualified class names in the jaif file, also when referring to classes in the same package that is being reported

booleanOption.label: jaif
booleanOption.name: jaif
booleanOption.description: dump a jaif file with the information flow information of the program
booleanOption.documentation: A jaif file is a compact report of the program places that might contain a secret (tainted) value. It can be used for reference and documentation, but can also be imported in the source code of the program by using the annotation file utilities (see http://types.cs.washington.edu/annotation-file-utilities)

booleanOption.label: mergeCreations
booleanOption.name: mergeCreations
booleanOption.description: merge the creation points for the same type inside the same class
booleanOption.documentation: This enhances the efficiency of the creation points analysis performed as part of flow analysis but, in general, reduces the precision of the analyzer. However, it can be an important option to select for the analysis of very large applications and in library mode, in the rare cases when the creation points analysis takes too long to complete. This option is automatically selected for large programs

booleanOption.label: noOracle
booleanOption.name: noOracle
booleanOption.description: do not use an oracle semantics for the fields
booleanOption.documentation: This largely reduces the precision of the analysis, since Julia will not track anymore the fields that are definitely initialized to a non-secret (non-tainted) value before being accessed. Mainly useful for profiling and statistics

booleanOption.label: noUnreachable
booleanOption.name: noUnreachable
booleanOption.description: do not dump information on unreachable code
booleanOption.documentation: By selecting this option, the jaif files become smaller

booleanOption.label: reportLocals
booleanOption.name: reportLocals
booleanOption.description: dump information on local variables
booleanOption.documentation: By selecting this option, the jaif file contains information on local variables as well and consequently becomes larger

booleanOption.label: trustDatabase
booleanOption.name: trustDatabase
booleanOption.description: consider data coming from a database query as trusted
booleanOption.documentation: This option lets Julia consider data coming from database queries as untainted and hence trusted. This is false by default

booleanOption.label: trustDevice
booleanOption.name: trustDevice
booleanOption.description: consider data about the specific device as trusted
booleanOption.documentation: This option lets Julia consider data about the specific device running the application as untainted and hence trusted. This is false by default

booleanOption.label: trustEnvironment
booleanOption.name: trustEnvironment
booleanOption.description: consider data coming from the running environment as trusted
booleanOption.documentation: This option lets Julia consider data coming from files or properties as untainted and hence trusted. This is true by default

booleanOption.label: trustExternalStreams
booleanOption.name: trustExternalStreams
booleanOption.description: consider data coming from external streams as trusted
booleanOption.documentation: This option lets Julia consider data coming from external streams and sockets as untainted and hence trusted. This is true by default

booleanOption.label: trustUserInput
booleanOption.name: trustUserInput
booleanOption.description: consider data from servlet requests and console as trusted
booleanOption.documentation: This option lets Julia consider data coming from servlet requests and console input as untainted and hence trusted. This is false by default
